subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
Originally an {{Han compound|å¤§||ä¸¨|t1=man|t2=tilted head|t3=cane|ls=ic|nocap=1}} â€“ a man with a cane looking around with his mouth wide open, not know where to go â€“ to be confused; to doubt. In the oracle bone script and bronze inscriptions, {{zh-l|*å½³}}, {{zh-l|*äº}}, and/or {{zh-l|*æ­¢}} was often added to indicate walking on a path.

Various phonetic components have been added later: {{och-l|ç‰›}} in the bronze script, {{och-l|å­}} or {{och-l|ä¹™}} in the bamboo and silk script, and {{och-l|å­}} or {{och-l|çŸ¢}} in the seal script. {{zh-l|*å­}} is perhaps a corruption of {{zh-l|*ç‰›}}.

By the seal script, the man has been corrupted to {{zh-l|*ğ ¤•}}, leading ''{{w|Shuowen}}'' to slightly misinterpret the character to represent â€œa child standing on an obstructed road to compare the pathsâ€: {{Han compound|å­|æ­¢|åŒ•|çŸ¢|c1=s|c2=s|c3=s|c4=p|t1=child|t2=to be obstructed|t3=to compare|nocap=1}}. {{w|Duan Yucai}}'s commentary on ''Shuowen'' offers an alternative interpretation, pointing out that {{och-l|çŸ¢}} is unlikely to be the phonetic component: {{Han compound|å­|ğ ¤•|æ­¢|c1=s|c2=s|c3=p|t1=child|t2=uncertain}}.

The current form is derived from the seal script, with more abstractions on the right ({{Han compound|å­|æ­¢}} becoming {{Han compound|ãƒ|ç–‹}}).
